newsitem.title: USA: American Skiing to buy two resorts for $288.3 mln.
newsitem.headline: American Skiing to buy two resorts for $288.3 mln.

text.p: American Skiing Co on Friday said it agreed to buy the Steamboat Ski Resort and the Heavenly Ski Resort from Kamori International Corp for $288.3 million.
The deal, expected to close in October, will make American Skiing the largest ski-resort company in the United States, ahead of rival Vail Resorts Inc, spokeswoman Cathleen Willis told Reuters.

Maine-based American Skiing -- which markets itself as the "Beast of the East" -- will have a major presence in the western United States after completion of the deal. Its western resorts will then account for more than half of its skier days -- an industry measure accounting for one customer skiing all or part of one day, spokesman Skip King said.

The Steamboat Ski Resort in Steamboat Springs, Colorado, and the Heavenly Ski Resort, which straddles the California and Nevada state lines near Lake Tahoe, will add an estimated 1.75 million skier days, the company said.

When the deal closes, American Skiing will own 11 ski resorts, with at least one in each major skiing market across the country. The 11 resorts combined for about 4.9 million skier days in the 1996-97 season, or about nine percent of the U.S. market.
Other terms of the transaction were not disclosed.
